text.text_translated: One night in 2003, during the US invasion of Iraq, Suzanne Collins was switching channels on TV. The only programmes she could find were reality shows where young people tried to win a million dollars, and news about the war. She says the two kinds of programmes began to mix in her mind in a worrying way. Then the idea for The Hunger Games (the title of her book) came to her.

feedback.feedback: The output is factually accurate and retains all key details from the original. The MeaningBERT score of 0.879 and BERTScore of 0.9584 confirm strong meaning preservation, and the text is correctly classified at B1 level. The sequence of events is clear and the vocabulary choices are appropriate for B1. To improve flow, consider varying your connectors: for example, use “while” instead of “during” in the first sentence (“One night in 2003, while the US was invading Iraq, Suzanne Collins…”) or start the third sentence with “Because” to show cause and effect (“Because she could only find those programmes…”). The parenthetical note “(the title of her book)” is accurate but could be integrated smoothly: “Then she had the idea for The Hunger Games, which became the title of her book.” These changes will make the narrative even more engaging and cohesive for B1 learners.
